name: 4-phenyl-2-chlorophenol
Reason: The basic unit for 4-phenyl-2-chlorophenol can be considered as benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The phenol (OH) group generally increases the melting point due to hydrogen bonding, which can add approximately +40 to +60°C. A chloro substituent (Cl) on the benzene ring also tends to increase the melting point due to increased molecular weight and polarity, adding around +20 to +30°C. An additional phenyl group contributes to the increase in melting point due to a larger molecular size, π-π interactions, and van der Waals forces, which would add around +15 to +25°C. Therefore, each functional group effect (the OH group, the Cl group, and the additional phenyl group) will add to the base melting point of benzene.
